[[Women in Egypt|Egyptian women]] were front and center, in news clips and on Facebook forums, and even in the leadership during the Egyptian revolution<ref name="The Middle Eastâs Feminist Revolution">{{cite news | last = Wolf | first = Naomi | agency = Project Syndicate | date = 2011-02-28 | url = http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/wolf33/English | title = The Middle Eastâs Feminist Revolution | publisher = Project-Syndicate.org | accessdate = 2011-03-01 }}</ref>. In Tahrir Square, women volunteers, some with their kids, worked to support the protests. Many commentators credited the great numbers of women and children with the remarkable overall peacefulness of the protesters in the face of grave provocations<ref name="The Middle Eastâs Feminist Revolution" />. Other citizen reporters in Tahrir Square noted that many women were involved in the protests as the protests were demographically inclusive<ref name="The Middle Eastâs Feminist Revolution" />. Many wore headscarves and other signs of religious conservatism, while others reveled in the freedom to kiss a friend or smoke a cigarette in public<ref name="The Middle Eastâs Feminist Revolution" />. Egyptian women also organized, strategized, and reported the events; Bloggers such as ''Leil Zahra Mortada'' took grave risks to keep the world informed daily of the scene in Tahrir Square and elsewhere<ref name="The Middle Eastâs Feminist Revolution" />.
